findings: The feature shows strong, clustered activation peaks that consistently appear at or near genes encoding transcriptional regulators (MarR family, LacI family, DeoR/GlpR family) and DNA-binding proteins. Examples include transcriptional regulators in Alicyclobacillus (sections 8), Granulosicoccus (section 6), and Peterkaempfera (section 2). The activation signal often appears at the 3' end of these genes or in the intergenic region immediately following them. Notably, the pattern is conserved across diverse bacterial phyla (Proteobacteria, Firmicutes, Spirochetes), suggesting an evolutionarily conserved DNA motif likely associated with transcription termination or regulatory elements following transcription factor genes.
conclusion: This feature captures a biologically meaningful pattern associated with the 3' regions of transcriptional regulator genes and DNA-binding proteins.
title: Transcriptional regulator 3' region motif
description: This feature detects a DNA sequence motif at or near the 3' end of transcriptional regulator genes and DNA-binding proteins. The activation pattern shows strong, clustered spikes that typically occur at the end of or immediately downstream of genes encoding various transcription factors (MarR, LacI, SARP, DeoR/GlpR families). The consistent positioning suggests this feature likely represents a termination signal, transcription factor binding site, or another regulatory element specifically associated with transcriptional regulators. The pattern is highly conserved across diverse bacterial phyla, including Proteobacteria (gamma and beta classes), Firmicutes, and Spirochetes, indicating its fundamental importance in bacterial gene regulation. This feature may capture elements involved in autoregulation of transcription factors or termination signals specific to these genes.
